head.title: Democracy in India Is Still Flourishing

hedline.hl1: Democracy in India Is Still Flourishing

abstract.p: Nathan Glazer letter says that as frequent visitor to India since 1966, he sees no rise in Indian nationalism or any fundamental weakening of Indian democracy (S)

block.p: Pankaj Mishra (''Yearning to Be Great, India Loses Its Way,'' Op-Ed, Sept. 16) asserts that in India secular democracy is being replaced by ''a unitary Hindu nationalism,'' and this explains the government's position on Kashmir. But every Indian government and leader from Nehru on has taken the same position on Kashmir, wisely or unwisely.

As a frequent visitor to India since 1966, I see no rise in Indian nationalism, or any fundamental weakening of Indian democracy. The current coalition government intervenes in the affairs of opposition-ruled states much less than previous governments, and formerly excluded groups have risen to power in the states and at the center.

Pankaj Mishra (''Yearning to Be Great, India Loses Its Way,'' Op-Ed, Sept. 16) asserts that in India secular democracy is being replaced by ''a unitary Hindu nationalism,'' and this explains the government's position on Kashmir. But every Indian government and leader from Nehru on has taken the same position on Kashmir, wisely or unwisely.

As a frequent visitor to India since 1966, I see no rise in Indian nationalism, or any fundamental weakening of Indian democracy. The current coalition government intervenes in the affairs of opposition-ruled states much less than previous governments, and formerly excluded groups have risen to power in the states and at the center.

The government should indeed address more forcefully the attacks by extremists on Christians and churches, but these outrages can be as little ascribed to Hinduism as the occasional attack on a synagogue in the United States can be ascribed to Christianity.
